an10.31:1.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā upāli yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā upāli bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an10.31:1.1.eng: Then Venerable Upāli went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

an10.31:1.2.pli: “kati nu kho, bhante, atthavase paṭicca tathāgatena sāvakānaṃ sikkhāpadaṃ paññattaṃ, pātimokkhaṃ uddiṭṭhan”ti?
an10.31:1.2.eng: “Sir, for how many reasons did the Realized One lay down training rules for his disciples and recite the monastic code?”

an10.31:2.1.pli: “Dasa kho, upāli, atthavase paṭicca tathāgatena sāvakānaṃ sikkhāpadaṃ paññattaṃ, pātimokkhaṃ uddiṭṭhaṃ.
an10.31:2.1.eng: “Upāli, the Realized One laid down training rules for his disciples and recited the monastic code for ten reasons.

an10.31:2.3.pli: Saṅghasuṭṭhutāya, saṅghaphāsutāya, dummaṅkūnaṃ puggalānaṃ niggahāya, pesalānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ phāsuvihārāya, diṭṭhadhammikānaṃ āsavānaṃ saṃvarāya, samparāyikānaṃ āsavānaṃ paṭighātāya, appasannānaṃ pasādāya, pasannānaṃ bhiyyobhāvāya, saddhammaṭṭhitiyā, vinayānuggahāya—
an10.31:2.3.eng: For the well-being of the Saṅgha and for the comfort of the Saṅgha. For keeping difficult individuals in check and for the comfort of good-hearted mendicants. For restraining defilements that affect this life and protecting against defilements that affect lives to come. For inspiring confidence in those without it, and increasing confidence in those who have it. For the continuation of the true teaching and the support of the training.

an10.31:2.4.pli: ime kho, upāli, dasa atthavase paṭicca tathāgatena sāvakānaṃ sikkhāpadaṃ paññattaṃ, pātimokkhaṃ uddiṭṭhan”ti.
an10.31:2.4.eng: The Realized One laid down training rules for his disciples and recited the monastic code for these ten reasons.”

an10.32:0.3.eng: Suspending the Recitation of the Monastic Code

an10.32:1.1.eng: “Sir, how many grounds are there to suspend the recitation of the monastic code?”

an10.32:1.2.eng: “Upāli, there are ten grounds to suspend the recitation of the monastic code.

an10.32:1.4.pli: Pārājiko tassaṃ parisāyaṃ nisinno hoti, pārājikakathā vippakatā hoti, anupasampanno tassaṃ parisāyaṃ nisinno hoti, anupasampannakathā vippakatā hoti, sikkhaṃ paccakkhātako tassaṃ parisāyaṃ nisinno hoti, sikkhaṃ paccakkhātakakathā vippakatā hoti, paṇḍako tassaṃ parisāyaṃ nisinno hoti, paṇḍakakathā vippakatā hoti, bhikkhunidūsako tassaṃ parisāyaṃ nisinno hoti, bhikkhunidūsakakathā vippakatā hoti—
an10.32:1.4.eng: A mendicant who has committed an expulsion offense is sitting in the assembly. A discussion about whether someone has committed an expulsion offense is unfinished. Someone who is not fully ordained is sitting in the assembly. A discussion about whether someone is fully ordained or not is unfinished. Someone who has resigned the training is sitting in the assembly. A discussion about whether someone has disavowed the training or not is unfinished. A eunuch is sitting in the assembly. A discussion about whether someone is a eunuch is unfinished. A raper of nuns is sitting in the assembly. A discussion about whether or not someone is a raper of nuns is unfinished.

an10.32:1.5.eng: These are the ten grounds to suspend the recitation of the monastic code.”

an10.33:1.1.pli: “Katihi nu kho, bhante, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu ubbāhikāya sammannitabbo”ti?
an10.33:1.1.eng: “Sir, how many qualities should a mendicant have to be deemed a judge?”

an10.33:1.2.pli: “Dasahi kho, upāli, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu ubbāhikāya sammannitabbo.
an10.33:1.2.eng: “Upāli, a mendicant should have ten qualities to be deemed a judge.

an10.33:1.4.pli: Idhupāli, bhikkhu sīlavā hoti; pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvuto viharati ācāragocarasampanno aṇumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvī, samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu;
an10.33:1.4.eng: It’s when a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.

an10.33:1.5.pli: bahussuto hoti sutadharo sutasannicayo, ye te dhammā ādikalyāṇā majjhekalyāṇā pariyosānakalyāṇā sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ abhivadanti, tathārūpāssa dhammā bahussutā honti dhātā vacasā paricitā manasānupekkhitā diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā;
an10.33:1.5.eng: They’re very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, rehearsing them, mentally scrutinizing them, and penetrating them theoretically.

an10.33:1.6.pli: ubhayāni kho panassa pātimokkhāni vitthārena svāgatāni honti suvibhattāni suppavattīni suvinicchitāni suttaso anubyañjanaso;
an10.33:1.6.eng: Both monastic codes have been passed down to them in detail, well analyzed, well mastered, well evaluated in both the rules and accompanying material.

an10.33:1.7.pli: vinaye kho pana ṭhito hoti asaṃhīro;
an10.33:1.7.eng: They’re firm and unfaltering in the training.

an10.33:1.8.pli: paṭibalo hoti ubho atthapaccatthike saññāpetuṃ paññāpetuṃ nijjhāpetuṃ pekkhetuṃ pasādetuṃ;
an10.33:1.8.eng: When there are opposing parties, they’re able to persuade, advocate, and convince them, make them see the other side and trust each other.

an10.33:1.9.eng: They’re skilled in raising and settling disciplinary issues.

an10.33:1.10.eng: They know what a disciplinary issue is.

an10.33:1.11.eng: They know how a disciplinary issue originates.

an10.33:1.12.eng: They know how a disciplinary issue ceases.

an10.33:1.13.eng: They know the practical way leading to the cessation of a disciplinary issue.

an10.33:1.14.pli: Imehi kho, upāli, dasahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu ubbāhikāya sammannitabbo”ti.
an10.33:1.14.eng: A mendicant should possess these ten qualities to be deemed a judge.”

an10.34:1.1.pli: “Katihi nu kho, bhante, dhammehi samannāgatena bhikkhunā upasampādetabban”ti?
an10.34:1.1.eng: “Sir, how many qualities should a mendicant have to give ordination?”

an10.34:1.2.pli: “Dasahi kho, upāli, dhammehi samannāgatena bhikkhunā upasampādetabbaṃ.
an10.34:1.2.eng: “Upāli, a mendicant should have ten qualities to give ordination.

an10.34:1.4.pli: Idhupāli, bhikkhu sīlavā hoti, pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvuto viharati ācāragocarasampanno aṇumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvī, samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu;
an10.34:1.4.eng: It’s when a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.

an10.34:1.5.pli: bahussuto hoti sutadharo sutasannicayo, ye te dhammā ādikalyāṇā majjhekalyāṇā pariyosānakalyāṇā sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ abhivadanti, tathārūpāssa dhammā bahussutā honti dhātā vacasā paricitā manasānupekkhitā diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā;
an10.34:1.5.eng: They’re very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, rehearsing them, mentally scrutinizing them, and penetrating them theoretically.

an10.34:1.6.pli: pātimokkhaṃ kho panassa vitthārena svāgataṃ hoti suvibhattaṃ suppavattaṃ suvinicchitaṃ suttaso anubyañjanaso;
an10.34:1.6.eng: Both monastic codes have been passed down to them in detail, well analyzed, well mastered, well evaluated in both the rules and accompanying material.

an10.34:1.7.pli: paṭibalo hoti gilānaṃ upaṭṭhātuṃ vā upaṭṭhāpetuṃ vā;
an10.34:1.7.eng: They’re able to care for the sick or get someone else to do so.

an10.34:1.8.pli: paṭibalo hoti anabhiratiṃ vūpakāsetuṃ vā vūpakāsāpetuṃ vā;
an10.34:1.8.eng: They’re able to settle dissatisfaction or get someone else to do so.

an10.34:1.9.pli: paṭibalo hoti uppannaṃ kukkuccaṃ dhammato vinodetuṃ;
an10.34:1.9.eng: They’re able to dispel remorse when it has come up.

an10.34:1.10.pli: paṭibalo hoti uppannaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ dhammato vivecetuṃ;
an10.34:1.10.eng: They’re able to rationally dissuade someone from misconceptions that come up.

an10.34:1.11.eng: They’re able to encourage someone in the higher ethics,

an10.34:1.14.pli: Imehi kho, upāli, dasahi dhammehi samannāgatena bhikkhunā upasampādetabban”ti.
an10.34:1.14.eng: A mendicant should possess these ten qualities to give ordination.”

an10.35:1.1.pli: “Katihi nu kho, bhante, dhammehi samannāgatena bhikkhunā nissayo dātabbo”ti?
an10.35:1.1.eng: “Sir, how many qualities should a mendicant have to give dependence?”

an10.35:1.2.pli: “Dasahi kho, upāli, dhammehi samannāgatena bhikkhunā nissayo dātabbo.
an10.35:1.2.eng: “Upāli, a mendicant should have ten qualities to give dependence.

an10.35:1.4.pli: Idhupāli, bhikkhu sīlavā hoti …pe… samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu;
an10.35:1.4.eng: It’s when a mendicant is ethical …

an10.35:1.6.pli: pātimokkhaṃ kho panassa vitthārena svāgataṃ hoti suvibhattaṃ suppavattaṃ suvinicchitaṃ suttaso anubyañjanaso;
an10.35:1.6.eng: Both monastic codes have been passed down to them in detail, well analyzed, well mastered, well evaluated in both the rules and accompanying material.

an10.35:1.7.pli: paṭibalo hoti gilānaṃ upaṭṭhātuṃ vā upaṭṭhāpetuṃ vā;
an10.35:1.7.eng: They’re able to care for the sick or get someone else to do so.

an10.35:1.8.pli: paṭibalo hoti anabhiratiṃ vūpakāsetuṃ vā vūpakāsāpetuṃ vā;
an10.35:1.8.eng: They’re able to settle dissatisfaction or get someone else to do so.

an10.35:1.9.pli: paṭibalo hoti uppannaṃ kukkuccaṃ dhammato vinodetuṃ;
an10.35:1.9.eng: They’re able to dispel remorse when it has come up.

an10.35:1.10.pli: paṭibalo hoti uppannaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ dhammato vivecetuṃ;
an10.35:1.10.eng: They’re able to rationally dissuade someone from misconceptions that come up.

an10.35:1.11.eng: They’re able to encourage someone in the higher ethics,

an10.35:1.14.pli: Imehi kho, upāli, dasahi dhammehi samannāgatena bhikkhunā nissayo dātabbo”ti.
an10.35:1.14.eng: A mendicant should possess these ten qualities to give dependence.”

an10.36:1.1.pli: “Katihi nu kho, bhante, dhammehi samannāgatena bhikkhunā sāmaṇero upaṭṭhāpetabbo”ti?
an10.36:1.1.eng: “Sir, how many qualities should a mendicant have to be attended on by a novice?”

an10.36:1.2.pli: “Dasahi kho, upāli, dhammehi samannāgatena bhikkhunā sāmaṇero upaṭṭhāpetabbo.
an10.36:1.2.eng: “Upāli, a mendicant should have ten qualities to be attended on by a novice.

an10.36:1.4.pli: Idhupāli, bhikkhu sīlavā hoti …pe… samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu;
an10.36:1.4.eng: It’s when a mendicant is ethical …

an10.36:1.6.pli: pātimokkhaṃ kho panassa vitthārena svāgataṃ hoti suvibhattaṃ suppavattaṃ suvinicchitaṃ suttaso anubyañjanaso;
an10.36:1.6.eng: Both monastic codes have been passed down to them in detail, well analyzed, well mastered, well evaluated in both the rules and accompanying material.

an10.36:1.7.pli: paṭibalo hoti gilānaṃ upaṭṭhātuṃ vā upaṭṭhāpetuṃ vā;
an10.36:1.7.eng: They’re able to care for the sick or get someone else to do so.

an10.36:1.8.pli: paṭibalo hoti anabhiratiṃ vūpakāsetuṃ vā vūpakāsāpetuṃ vā;
an10.36:1.8.eng: They’re able to settle dissatisfaction or get someone else to do so.

an10.36:1.9.pli: paṭibalo hoti uppannaṃ kukkuccaṃ dhammato vinodetuṃ;
an10.36:1.9.eng: They’re able to dispel remorse when it has come up.

an10.36:1.10.pli: paṭibalo hoti uppannaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ dhammato vivecetuṃ;
an10.36:1.10.eng: They’re able to rationally dissuade someone from misconceptions that come up.

an10.36:1.11.eng: They’re able to encourage someone in the higher ethics,

an10.36:1.14.pli: Imehi kho, upāli, dasahi dhammehi samannāgatena bhikkhunā sāmaṇero upaṭṭhāpetabbo”ti.
an10.36:1.14.eng: A mendicant should possess these ten qualities to be attended on by a novice.”

an10.37:1.1.eng: “Sir, they speak of ‘schism in the Saṅgha’.

an10.37:1.2.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, saṅgho bhinno hotī”ti?
an10.37:1.2.eng: How is schism in the Saṅgha defined?”

an10.37:1.3.pli: “Idhupāli, bhikkhū adhammaṃ dhammoti dīpenti, dhammaṃ adhammoti dīpenti, avinayaṃ vinayoti dīpenti, vinayaṃ avinayoti dīpenti, abhāsitaṃ alapitaṃ tathāgatena bhāsitaṃ lapitaṃ tathāgatenāti dīpenti, bhāsitaṃ lapitaṃ tathāgatena abhāsitaṃ alapitaṃ tathāgatenāti dīpenti, anāciṇṇaṃ tathāgatena āciṇṇaṃ tathāgatenāti dīpenti, āciṇṇaṃ tathāgatena anāciṇṇaṃ tathāgatenāti dīpenti, apaññattaṃ tathāgatena paññattaṃ tathāgatenāti dīpenti, paññattaṃ tathāgatena apaññattaṃ tathāgatenāti dīpenti.
an10.37:1.3.eng: “Upāli, it’s when a mendicant explains what is not the teaching as the teaching, and what is the teaching as not the teaching. They explain what is not the training as the training, and what is the training as not the training. They explain what was not spoken and stated by the Realized One as spoken and stated by the Realized One, and what was spoken and stated by the Realized One as not spoken and stated by the Realized One. They explain what was not practiced by the Realized One as practiced by the Realized One, and what was practiced by the Realized One as not practiced by the Realized One. They explain what was not prescribed by the Realized One as prescribed by the Realized One, and what was prescribed by the Realized One as not prescribed by the Realized One.

an10.37:1.4.pli: Te imehi dasahi vatthūhi avakassanti apakassanti āveni kammāni karonti āveni pātimokkhaṃ uddisanti.
an10.37:1.4.eng: On these ten grounds they split off and go their own way. They perform legal acts autonomously and recite the monastic code autonomously.

an10.37:1.5.pli: Ettāvatā kho, upāli, saṅgho bhinno hotī”ti.
an10.37:1.5.eng: That is how schism in the Saṅgha is defined.”

an10.38:1.1.eng: “Sir, they speak of ‘harmony in the Saṅgha’.

an10.38:1.2.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, saṅgho samaggo hotī”ti?
an10.38:1.2.eng: How is harmony in the Saṅgha defined?”

an10.38:1.3.pli: “Idhupāli, bhikkhū adhammaṃ adhammoti dīpenti, dhammaṃ dhammoti dīpenti, avinayaṃ avinayoti dīpenti, vinayaṃ vinayoti dīpenti, abhāsitaṃ alapitaṃ tathāgatena abhāsitaṃ alapitaṃ tathāgatenāti dīpenti, bhāsitaṃ lapitaṃ tathāgatena bhāsitaṃ lapitaṃ tathāgatenāti dīpenti, anāciṇṇaṃ tathāgatena anāciṇṇaṃ tathāgatenāti dīpenti, āciṇṇaṃ tathāgatena āciṇṇaṃ tathāgatenāti dīpenti, apaññattaṃ tathāgatena apaññattaṃ tathāgatenāti dīpenti, paññattaṃ tathāgatena paññattaṃ tathāgatenāti dīpenti.
an10.38:1.3.eng: “Upāli, it’s when a mendicant explains what is not the teaching as not the teaching, and what is the teaching as the teaching. They explain what is not the training as not the training, and what is the training as the training. They explain what was not spoken and stated by the Realized One as not spoken and stated by the Realized One, and what was spoken and stated by the Realized One as spoken and stated by the Realized One. They explain what was not practiced by the Realized One as not practiced by the Realized One, and what was practiced by the Realized One as practiced by the Realized One. They explain what was not prescribed by the Realized One as not prescribed by the Realized One, and what was prescribed by the Realized One as prescribed by the Realized One.

an10.38:1.4.pli: Te imehi dasahi vatthūhi na avakassanti na apakassanti na āveni kammāni karonti na āveni pātimokkhaṃ uddisanti.
an10.38:1.4.eng: On these ten grounds they don’t split off and go their own way. They don’t perform legal acts autonomously or recite the monastic code autonomously.

an10.38:1.5.pli: Ettāvatā kho, upāli, saṅgho samaggo hotī”ti.
an10.38:1.5.eng: That is how harmony in the Saṅgha is defined.”

an10.39:1.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an10.39:1.1.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to the Buddha:

an10.39:1.2.eng: “Sir, they speak of ‘schism in the Saṅgha’.

an10.39:1.3.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, saṅgho bhinno hotī”ti?
an10.39:1.3.eng: How is schism in the Saṅgha defined?”

an10.39:1.4.pli: “Idhānanda, bhikkhū adhammaṃ dhammoti dīpenti, dhammaṃ adhammoti dīpenti, avinayaṃ vinayoti dīpenti …pe…
an10.39:1.4.eng: “Ānanda, it’s when a mendicant explains what is not the teaching as the teaching …

an10.39:1.5.eng: and what was prescribed by the Realized One as not prescribed by the Realized One.

an10.39:1.6.pli: Te imehi dasahi vatthūhi avakassanti apakassanti āveni kammāni karonti āveni pātimokkhaṃ uddisanti.
an10.39:1.6.eng: On these ten grounds they split off and go their own way. They perform legal acts autonomously and recite the monastic code autonomously.

an10.39:1.7.pli: Ettāvatā kho, ānanda, saṅgho bhinno hotī”ti.
an10.39:1.7.eng: That is how schism in the Saṅgha is defined.”

an10.39:2.1.pli: “Samaggaṃ pana, bhante, saṅghaṃ bhinditvā kiṃ so pasavatī”ti?
an10.39:2.1.eng: “But sir, what does someone who has split a harmonious Saṅgha brim with?”

an10.39:2.2.eng: “They brim with sin that lasts for an eon.”

an10.39:2.3.eng: “But sir, what is the sin that lasts for an eon?”

an10.39:2.4.eng: “They burn in hell for an eon, Ānanda.

an10.39:3.1.eng: A schismatic remains for the eon

an10.39:3.2.eng: in a place of loss, in hell.

an10.39:3.3.eng: Taking a stand against the teaching,

an10.39:3.4.eng: favoring factions, they ruin their sanctuary.

an10.39:3.5.eng: After causing schism in a harmonious Saṅgha,

an10.39:3.6.eng: they burn in hell for an eon.”

an10.4:1.1.pli: Tatra kho āyasmā sāriputto bhikkhū āmantesi …pe…
an10.4:1.1.eng: There Venerable Sāriputta addressed the mendicants …

an10.4:1.2.eng: “Reverends, an unethical person, who lacks ethics, has destroyed a vital condition for having no regrets.

an10.4:1.3.eng: When there are regrets, one who has regrets has destroyed a vital condition for joy. …

an10.4:1.4.eng: One who lacks disillusionment and dispassion has destroyed a vital condition for knowledge and vision of freedom.

an10.4:1.5.pli: Seyyathāpi, āvuso, rukkho sākhāpalāsavipanno. Tassa papaṭikāpi na pāripūriṃ gacchati, tacopi … pheggupi … sāropi na pāripūriṃ gacchati.
an10.4:1.5.eng: Suppose there was a tree that lacked branches and foliage. Its shoots, bark, softwood, and heartwood would not grow to fullness.

an10.4:1.6.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, āvuso, dussīlassa sīlavipannassa hatūpaniso hoti avippaṭisāro;
an10.4:1.6.eng: In the same way, an unethical person, who lacks ethics, has destroyed a vital condition for having no regrets.

an10.4:1.7.eng: When there are regrets, one who has regrets has destroyed a vital condition for joy. …

an10.4:1.8.eng: One who lacks disillusionment and dispassion has destroyed a vital condition for knowledge and vision of freedom.

an10.4:2.1.pli: Sīlavato, āvuso, sīlasampannassa upanisasampanno hoti avippaṭisāro;
an10.4:2.1.eng: An ethical person, who has fulfilled ethics, has fulfilled a vital condition for not having regrets.

an10.4:2.2.eng: When there are no regrets, one who has no regrets has fulfilled a vital condition for joy. …

an10.4:2.3.eng: One who has fulfilled disillusionment and dispassion has fulfilled a vital condition for knowledge and vision of freedom.

an10.4:2.4.pli: Seyyathāpi, āvuso, rukkho sākhāpalāsasampanno. Tassa papaṭikāpi pāripūriṃ gacchati, tacopi … pheggupi … sāropi pāripūriṃ gacchati.
an10.4:2.4.eng: Suppose there was a tree that was complete with branches and foliage. Its shoots, bark, softwood, and heartwood would grow to fullness.

an10.4:2.5.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, āvuso, sīlavato sīlasampannassa upanisasampanno hoti avippaṭisāro;
an10.4:2.5.eng: In the same way, an ethical person, who has fulfilled ethics, has fulfilled a vital condition for not having regrets.

an10.4:2.6.eng: When there are no regrets, one who has no regrets has fulfilled a vital condition for joy. …

an10.4:2.7.eng: One who has fulfilled disillusionment and dispassion has fulfilled a vital condition for knowledge and vision of freedom.”

an10.40:1.1.eng: “Sir, they speak of ‘harmony in the Saṅgha’.

an10.40:1.2.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, saṅgho samaggo hotī”ti?
an10.40:1.2.eng: How is harmony in the Saṅgha defined?”

an10.40:1.3.pli: “Idhānanda, bhikkhū adhammaṃ adhammoti dīpenti, dhammaṃ dhammoti dīpenti, avinayaṃ avinayoti dīpenti, vinayaṃ vinayoti dīpenti, abhāsitaṃ alapitaṃ tathāgatena abhāsitaṃ alapitaṃ tathāgatenāti dīpenti, bhāsitaṃ lapitaṃ tathāgatena bhāsitaṃ lapitaṃ tathāgatenāti dīpenti, anāciṇṇaṃ tathāgatena anāciṇṇaṃ tathāgatenāti dīpenti, āciṇṇaṃ tathāgatena āciṇṇaṃ tathāgatenāti dīpenti, apaññattaṃ tathāgatena apaññattaṃ tathāgatenāti dīpenti, paññattaṃ tathāgatena paññattaṃ tathāgatenāti dīpenti.
an10.40:1.3.eng: “Ānanda, it’s when a mendicant explains what is not the teaching as not the teaching, and what is the teaching as the teaching. They explain what is not the training as not the training, and what is the training as the training. They explain what was not spoken and stated by the Realized One as not spoken and stated by the Realized One, and what was spoken and stated by the Realized One as spoken and stated by the Realized One. They explain what was not practiced by the Realized One as not practiced by the Realized One, and what was practiced by the Realized One as practiced by the Realized One. They explain what was not prescribed by the Realized One as not prescribed by the Realized One, and what was prescribed by the Realized One as prescribed by the Realized One.

an10.40:1.4.pli: Te imehi dasahi vatthūhi na avakassanti na apakassanti na āveni kammāni karonti na āveni pātimokkhaṃ uddisanti.
an10.40:1.4.eng: On these ten grounds they don’t split off and go their own way. They don’t perform legal acts autonomously or recite the monastic code autonomously.

an10.40:1.5.pli: Ettāvatā kho, ānanda, saṅgho samaggo hotī”ti.
an10.40:1.5.eng: That is how harmony in the Saṅgha is defined.”

an10.40:2.1.pli: “Bhinnaṃ pana, bhante, saṅghaṃ samaggaṃ katvā kiṃ so pasavatī”ti?
an10.40:2.1.eng: “But sir, what does someone who has forged harmony in a schismatic Saṅgha brim with?”

an10.40:2.4.eng: “They rejoice in heaven for an eon, Ānanda.

an10.40:3.1.eng: A Saṅgha in harmony is happy,

an10.40:3.2.eng: as is support for those in harmony.

an10.40:3.3.eng: Taking a stand on the teaching,

an10.40:3.4.eng: favoring harmony, they ruin no sanctuary.

an10.40:3.5.eng: After forging harmony in the Saṅgha,

an10.40:3.6.eng: they rejoice in heaven for an eon.”

an10.41:1.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā upāli yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā upāli bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an10.41:1.1.eng: Then Venerable Upāli went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

an10.41:1.2.pli: “ko nu kho, bhante, hetu ko paccayo, yena saṅghe bhaṇḍanakalahaviggahavivādā uppajjanti, bhikkhū ca na phāsu viharantī”ti?
an10.41:1.2.eng: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason, why fights, quarrels, arguments, and disputes arise in the Saṅgha, and the mendicants don’t live happily?”

an10.41:1.3.pli: “Idhupāli, bhikkhū adhammaṃ dhammoti dīpenti, dhammaṃ adhammoti dīpenti, avinayaṃ vinayoti dīpenti, vinayaṃ avinayoti dīpenti, abhāsitaṃ alapitaṃ tathāgatena bhāsitaṃ lapitaṃ tathāgatenāti dīpenti, bhāsitaṃ lapitaṃ tathāgatena abhāsitaṃ alapitaṃ tathāgatenāti dīpenti, anāciṇṇaṃ tathāgatena āciṇṇaṃ tathāgatenāti dīpenti, āciṇṇaṃ tathāgatena anāciṇṇaṃ tathāgatenāti dīpenti, apaññattaṃ tathāgatena paññattaṃ tathāgatenāti dīpenti, paññattaṃ tathāgatena apaññattaṃ tathāgatenāti dīpenti.
an10.41:1.3.eng: “Upāli, it’s when a mendicant explains what is not the teaching as the teaching, and what is the teaching as not the teaching. They explain what is not the training as the training, and what is the training as not the training. They explain what was not spoken and stated by the Realized One as spoken and stated by the Realized One, and what was spoken and stated by the Realized One as not spoken and stated by the Realized One. They explain what was not practiced by the Realized One as practiced by the Realized One, and what was practiced by the Realized One as not practiced by the Realized One. They explain what was not prescribed by the Realized One as prescribed by the Realized One, and what was prescribed by the Realized One as not prescribed by the Realized One.

an10.41:1.4.pli: Ayaṃ kho, upāli, hetu ayaṃ paccayo, yena saṅghe bhaṇḍanakalahaviggahavivādā uppajjanti, bhikkhū ca na phāsu viharantī”ti.
an10.41:1.4.eng: This is the cause, this is the reason why fights, quarrels, arguments, and disputes arise in the Saṅgha, and the mendicants don’t live happily.”

an10.42:1.1.eng: “Sir, how many roots of dispute are there?”

an10.42:1.2.eng: “Upāli, there are ten roots of dispute.

an10.42:1.4.pli: Idhupāli, bhikkhū adhammaṃ dhammoti dīpenti, dhammaṃ adhammoti dīpenti, avinayaṃ vinayoti dīpenti, vinayaṃ avinayoti dīpenti, abhāsitaṃ alapitaṃ tathāgatena bhāsitaṃ lapitaṃ tathāgatenāti dīpenti, bhāsitaṃ lapitaṃ tathāgatena abhāsitaṃ alapitaṃ tathāgatenāti dīpenti, anāciṇṇaṃ tathāgatena āciṇṇaṃ tathāgatenāti dīpenti, āciṇṇaṃ tathāgatena anāciṇṇaṃ tathāgatenāti dīpenti, apaññattaṃ tathāgatena paññattaṃ tathāgatenāti dīpenti, paññattaṃ tathāgatena apaññattaṃ tathāgatenāti dīpenti.
an10.42:1.4.eng: It’s when a mendicant explains what is not the teaching as the teaching, and what is the teaching as not the teaching. They explain what is not the training as the training, and what is the training as not the training. They explain what was not spoken and stated by the Realized One as spoken and stated by the Realized One, and what was spoken and stated by the Realized One as not spoken and stated by the Realized One. They explain what was not practiced by the Realized One as practiced by the Realized One, and what was practiced by the Realized One as not practiced by the Realized One. They explain what was not prescribed by the Realized One as prescribed by the Realized One, and what was prescribed by the Realized One as not prescribed by the Realized One.

an10.42:1.5.eng: These are the ten roots of dispute.”

an10.43:1.1.eng: “Sir, how many roots of dispute are there?”

an10.43:1.2.eng: “Upāli, there are ten roots of disputes.

an10.43:1.4.pli: Idhupāli, bhikkhū anāpattiṃ āpattīti dīpenti, āpattiṃ anāpattīti dīpenti, lahukaṃ āpattiṃ garukāpattīti dīpenti, garukaṃ āpattiṃ lahukāpattīti dīpenti, duṭṭhullaṃ āpattiṃ aduṭṭhullāpattīti dīpenti, aduṭṭhullaṃ āpattiṃ duṭṭhullāpattīti dīpenti, sāvasesaṃ āpattiṃ anavasesāpattīti dīpenti, anavasesaṃ āpattiṃ sāvasesāpattīti dīpenti, sappaṭikammaṃ āpattiṃ appaṭikammāpattīti dīpenti, appaṭikammaṃ āpattiṃ sappaṭikammāpattīti dīpenti.
an10.43:1.4.eng: It’s when a mendicant explains what is not an offense as an offense, and what is an offense as not an offense. They explain a light offense as a serious offense, and a serious offense as a light offense. They explain an offense committed with corrupt intention as an offense not committed with corrupt intention, and an offense not committed with corrupt intention as an offense committed with corrupt intention. They explain an offense requiring rehabilitation as an offense not requiring rehabilitation, and an offense not requiring rehabilitation as an offense requiring rehabilitation. They explain an offense with redress as an offense without redress, and an offense without redress as an offense with redress.

an10.43:1.5.eng: These are the ten roots of dispute.”
